case_vignette: A 40-year-old female complains about squamous papules on her scalp for 10 years. These lesions responded to topical corticosteroids but recurs when the treatment is stopped. She denies any systemic symptoms. Physical exam reveals erythematous scaly papules with signs of atrophy and scarring, as well as cicatricial alopecia. Skin biopsy shows lichenoid interface dermatitis with hyperkeratosis and follicular plugging.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have had small, rough bumps on my scalp for 10 years that get better with a cream, but they come back when I stop using the cream.
What type of cream have you been using for these bumps?
I've been using a cream that contains corticosteroids.
Do these bumps itch or cause any discomfort?
No, I don't have any itching or discomfort from these bumps.
Have you ever had a biopsy done on any of the bumps?
Yes, I had a biopsy done on one of the bumps.
What was the result of the biopsy?
The biopsy showed a type of inflammation with excessive hardening and blockage at the hair follicles.
Final Diagnosis: Keratosis Pilaris

trial_0.summarized_conversation: The patient has been experiencing small, rough bumps on his scalp for 10 years. These bumps improve with the application of a cream, but recur upon discontinuation. The cream used contains corticosteroids. Despite the presence of these bumps, the patient reports no itching or discomfort. A biopsy performed on one of the bumps revealed inflammation characterized by excessive hardening and blockage at the hair follicles.
